It wasn't until I pointed that out that she added it--all the while acting like I owed her a favor.  I ended up not eating here as the wait was too long and it was clear they didn't want my business. Was looking forward to trying to food but I guess that will never happen. I'm all for small businesses but this is one business that needs to reorganize.

aPW9J80tYYulVievRkWO0A.text: Excellent (applewood smoked) bacon.  I ordered a side and got a healthy portion for the $3 price.  The coffee is also excellent.    The menu is exciting and the ingredients are fresh.  Staff was attentive.  Prices are a little high, but I guess considering the options and the hipster atmosphere it's to be expected.  I had the Challah French Toast and also tried the Apple Cinnamon Panini.  They serve up healthy portions and both were tasty.  I might go again, but definitely not on a weekend when I'd have to wait.  I'd recommend giving it a try, but I'd also recommend going on a weekday when they open at 7am and it's not busy or crowded.

Jy0kQ1CISVrUFSnPqbO6vA.text: We have been to Coca Cafe many times. Was just so disappointed today. Service was greatly lacking. Food was barely mediocre. The poached eggs (which I look forward to) were hard boiled. The fruit cup was all pineapple. In the past, fruit cup was a variety of fruit that was delicious. No refills on drinks whatsoever. Will take quite awhile before I go back if I do.

IcEwhxX2mGuWzCt8QPLTow.text: A lovely place for brunch with both healthy and decadent options to please everyone at your table! I opted for the shakshuka- the tomato sauce had a wonderful level of heat offset by the creaminess of the feta. The pineapple lemon ginger cayenne juice was refreshing and playful. The interior is warmly decorated & the service is brisk, but friendly.

photos.caption: Photo of Coca Cafe - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Brunch spread!
Photo of Coca Cafe - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pineapple lemon ginger cayenne juice
Photo of Coca Cafe - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Shakshuka- nice kick in the sauce!

Q94GaEMe8dYQoMg3rwUYuA.text: This has been my go to place for a long time. But last experience was below par. My shakshuka was still partially cooked, they did take it back and bake ir further but it just didn't quite sit right with me. There was no wait for a sitting place but they told us once we were seated that there was a 45 minute delay for whatever food we would order. My salmon omelette also left a lot to be desired. I'm generally someone who never leaves a bite on the plate but this time I left most of my food behind. I basically paid 60 dollars to sit and wish I was somewhere else, eating something else. Would not recommend this as a brunch place on the weekends.

qLmZWyqWkn26uLDuPAIFBg.text: DO NOT GO TO THIS RESTAURANT. Unless you want absolutely poor service, rude waitresses, sharp objects, and to wait an hour for average food,  DO NOT GO TO COCA. We came in as a group of five and were greeted with a small, 3 seat, dirty table. After being seated, we (tried) to order the coca mocha, and were informed that it had run out (at 10:20 am). My friend instead ordered a mimosa that was less mimosa than simply crushed up ice. Next, we tried to order appetizers, and were informed that the donuts were also sold out (10:40 am). We instead ordered the zucchini bread (actually banana bread) which was served plain with butter. Upon asking questions about the menu, I was received with an arrogant response about what to order. Cue the FORTY MINUTE wait for food. We ordered three full entrees (omelet, eggs, French toast). The other orders were simply avocado toast, bacon, and potatoes. I do not know about you, but I can make avocado toast in about 5 minutes in my own kitchen. The food was average at best, and my friend swallowed a sharp object in her French toast. Upon receiving the bill, there was a 20% tip WRITTEN IN at the bottom. It looked more like a suggestion than an official bill. NO WHERE on the menu was there a stipulation indicating that parties of 5+ should have gratuity added. Had this been written, it would have been honored, however as a customer paying for quite frankly overpriced food for mediocre quality and sub par service, a 20% tip was not justified nor deserved. Upon confronting our waitress both about the shard of glass in the food and the tip situation, we were told "it is policy", "we are renovating the menus" "it is a mom and pop shop, we can do what we want". It is not a policy if it is not written. If I say the sky is pink, does that make it so? NO. It does not. We were finally refunded our tip, but offered no apology. Upon leaving what we saw fit, we left the restaurant, in agreement within our group to never return. At this point we were followed out by our waitress (whose name we never learned) and asked to never come back and informed that our behavior was unacceptable. Given the circumstances, we were diplomats. It will be our pleasure to never return to this awful place. Save your time, save your money, GO SOMEWHERE ELSE.

nqTH_oC7O8RclLw8LN6qzg.text: Coca Cafe let me just say it's like preforming a dropkick of healthy eating in the heat of May. As if you were understandably taken prey, you could find yourself by a bay yelling "Yay". A buffet of tastes won't bring up dismay, your tongue will leap as the flavors begin to play.   A ballet of selection, don't worry your wallet won't over pay.. my terrific omelet was filled with chopped up salmon fillet. By the time you leave, you will wish you could stay, Coca Cafe will be remembered in your heart more than Jean Baptiste Pierre Antoine De Monet.

photos.caption: Photo of Coca Cafe - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

xBKaXThUOLivhUS5VVqSZA.text: Highly underrated for dinner. They put a lot of thought into the dishes- which change frequently. The food is excellent and diverse but it is more tapas style than anything. I'll stress that some of the dishes miss the mark but your server will be happy to help guide you.    Have only been here once for breakfast but it was phenomenal. Expect long wait times on the weekend for breakfast.   A little pricey- but it's BYOB so that adds to the value of the equation. Excellent service however the wait times aren't always amazing because of how small the kitchen is.   Will definitely be coming back- perfect for a nice, long unAmerican style dinner.

s6cNA9v1W0TlZok-VtUZyA.text: I live a few streets over, and couldn't believe I had never been to Coca before. So finally, a couple of months ago, I made it a point to go to a weekend brunch.  Luckily, we got there early enough to beat the crowd. This place gets PACKED. The sidewalk outside of it is a nightmare if you're strolling by - there's ALWAYS people outside. If you are with a group, be sure to only send one person inside to put your name in, because it gets pretty tight inside.  Service was bad and slow. I felt bad for the waitress though. Seemed understaffed that day or something. We didn't end up getting half of what we ordered because she would never come back to our table.   The food's good. It's pretentious, pricey brunch and they have some cool menu items. (I had some sort of brisket/grits dish.) It's not special enough for me to fight through swarms of people and deal with the poor service.

Gt_untcbJMdhP95edNDTnQ.text: Went there for breakfast/brunch on a recent weekend.  The food was well-prepared, but service was painfully slow.  I got a sense that the kitchen can't handle order volume well, and the waiter seemed distracted and unsure what to do.   Used to be a real gem, but they need to get their act together service wise.

ZObd6bQOlutZCbHTUM_Q5Q.text: What a find! Thank you Pitttsburgh yelpers for leading me to this wonderful restaurant!  The building looks like a house turned restaurant, with an array of colors inside, cute paintings on the wall, and a welcoming atmosphere.  We arrived around 12:15pm on a friday afternoon.  We waited 30 minutes but it was well worth it!  My boyfriend and I both enjoyed free refills on coffee :) He ordered the Salmon BLT and I ordered the Chicken and Brie Sandwich with a side of potatoes.  We actually ended up switching plates because the Salmon BLT is  more savory than the Chicken and Brie Sandwich.  Salmon BLT: One of the most AMAZING SANDWICHES I have ever had. The bread was toasted, the salmon was moist, crisp bacon with field greens and tomatoes made me a very, very happy customer.  Chicken and Brie Sandwich: I found the chicken a little on the dry side or maybe I was craving for some mayo like component to finish the sandwich a bit more. It's sweeter than an avg sandwich with the melted brie cheese and the thinly sliced apples.  I may have found it just okay, but my boyfriend loved it!  side of Potatoes: I always order a side of potatoes at breakfast places if my dish doesn't already come with it.  They were good but I needed to add my own salt and pepper.  Total plus tax and tip came to be $27.  I'm definitely going to come back for brunch again next time I visit Pittsburgh! This is a great choice if you're looking to catch up with a friend over a cup of coffee or if you want to find a good breakfast/lunch that isn't a greasy spoon kinda place.

photos.caption: Photo of Coca Cafe - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Coca Cafe - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

QIPLXdcDojy4ebI6qeVmjg.text: One of my most favorite brunch spots. Consistently delicious. Herbed goat cheese stuffed French toast is the best. Wait can be long, but get your name on the list, it's worth it. Pro tip: Walk down the street to Espresso A Mano and get some coffee while you wait for your table!

lgq3GEyea5S5oEpsfE84bw.text: Great food, terrible service.  We waited ... for everything!   Everyone was pleased with their meal.  I ordered the quinoa breakfast and took notes to replicate at home.   They charged us for a fresh juice that never showed up even after inquiring numerous times. Took FOREVER to correct the bill.  What a shame. They really have good food.

1_Z3eWNP0MSczSLTpW0-wQ.text: I stopped by here a few Sunday's ago with my fiance for an early Sunday brunch.  We were hoping to beat most of brunch crowd there and arrived around 10:30 without using the call ahead seating.  This proved to be a mistake as there was already a wait whenever we got there.  The wait only ended up being 10 minutes or so but the lack of places to wait made it interesting as we had to move off to the side anytime someone wanted to get into or out of the restaurant.  I can't really remember much of the decor of this place although the restaurant was broken up into two distinct dining areas.  The front room was decently spacious with larger tables and the huge front windows providing a ton of light.  The back room was more for the smaller tables as they had a lot of two top booths with the light coming in from side windows.  For my brunch entree I decided to go with the fried eggplant benedict  while my fiance decided to start off with the crab bisque followed by an entree of the sun dried tomato pesto omelet.  My fiances soup was the first item to come out of the kitchen and onto our table and boy was it a large bowl of bisque.  It was also loaded with lump crab meat which surprised me as normally places take the easy way out and just have a few pieces of meat with most of the flavoring belonging to the bisque.  The soup itself was really good being thick and creamy with a nice little taste of sherry in it.  After we had finished the bowl of soup our entrees came out.  My entree consisted of the fried eggplant with a basil pesto hollandaise, poached eggs and some breakfast potatoes.  The eggplant ended tasting decently as did the hollandaise and the potatoes. However I wasn't as enamored with the dish as I expected to be.  I figured that there were two reasons why with one of them having the restaurant being over-hyped to me.  The other is that maybe I once again made a poor entree selection for myself.  The latter is probably most like the truth as I thought my fiances omelet was fantastic, especially the Provence Salami and Buffalo Mozzarella.  The bottom line for me is that I would head back here again in the future.  It wouldn't be my first choice of brunch places but I would be interested to see if I chose poorly since all of my fiances food seemed to taste pretty good.

xd574Z3mN2P-8tZzOn8dOQ.text: The long and the short of it: GREAT food, coffee drinks outside of regular lattes are way too sweet, and the wait for said drinks to be made is long. They could probably tighten up service with more hands on deck to expo drinks. Otherwise their menu items are diverse and we left with happy bellies. My lavender steamer was way too sweet and they swapped it with a regular latte no problem (thank you!).

GuMujJUUjhNp00I9mmWVWg.text: I initially came with pretty low expectations because it had 3.5 stars but I left impressed!!   We went on a Saturday morning and there was no wait for us so we got seated right away. The building lets a lot of sunlight come in and we were seated in the back so it was breezy and nice. I ordered the avocado omelette and my friend ordered eggs cooked in the red sauce (don't remember the name)   The omelette was good! Fluffy and thick with a dollop of fresh salsa and guac on top, I wasn't disappointed. I loved how they included a slice of watermelon because after the flavor heavy egg and the buttery bread it was so refreshing. My friend also enjoyed the eggs very much. I liked this place because it was unique, breakfast places can make the mistake of being too generic but the environment and food of this place was memorable. Service was alright - right after we got our food, our waitress placed the check on our table so I definitively felt a bit rushed. Will be returning in the future!

photos.caption: Photo of Coca Cafe - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

vd1vYlxRpG2i1uth5dejsw.text: Almost 2 hours for an omelet. The label of a an avocado and two tops with in the mash. Totally unexpected

LTkMB4TT9VprV-DGZMRnPg.text: There are few things in life that bring me as much joy as Sunday brunch. When I heard Coca Cafe was one of the best brunch spots in Pittsburgh, I had to stop by to judge for myself.   Tip #1: Use the Nowait app otherwise you'll be standing around for at least an hour waiting for a table.  Almost all the menu items were vegetarian - great first impression. I took a walk on the wild side and went with the Shakshuka. Contrary to the menu description, it was not spicy at all. Although I found my meal to be very enjoyable, it was not exactly the mind blowing experience I was expecting. My boyfriend felt the same about his Avocado Omelette.   The service was one of the worst experiences I've had in a while. Aside from the painfully slow service, our waitress brought out the wrong drinks then overcharged us on the bill.   I would agree, the food here tastes great, but definitely NOT worth wasting half my precious Sunday morning for. On to the next brunch spot.

photos.caption: Photo of Coca Cafe - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Avocado Omelette
Photo of Coca Cafe - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Shakshuka

6DRiFP7FTzaVhSSp1lMWQg.text: The menu is varied and has some interesting dishes. There are enough options to find a few things that appeal to you without being overwhelming. We went for brunch, where I got the salmon soft scramble. I wasn't the biggest fan of the soft scramble (kinda watery and tasteless aside from the salmon), but it was fresh and there was plenty of salmon in it. The breakfast potatoes that accompanied it weren't the greatest- kind of hard and not very flavorful. Everybody else though seemed to enjoy their food a lot, and I would definitely come back to try one of the other delicious sounding options on the menu.  I did take off a star for service. We used the "no wait" app to get in line and arrived at our designed time, yet still had to wait over 20 minutes to be seated. Once we were seated, the service wasn't much faster. To be fair, the woman waiting on us did seem harried so it's not like this was due to laziness, but still, it seems as though other reviews have noted the slow service as well so maybe they should hire more servers. It wasn't even a particularly busy day either when we went

xq3HXfY13-8TTZ_AaARtTA.text: 4.5 stars for food, 2 stars for service. Sounds like I'm not the first to have this lopsided experience at Coca Cafe in recent months. I had the lavender latte to drink. Nicely sweetened, good lavender flavor. Something I won't make for myself at home, so a nice treat. For brunch, I had one of the eggs Benedict options--the club. Toasted bread in place of the English muffin, avocado, the classic poached egg, basil hollandaise, two slices of thick cut bacon and a little salty, savory chorizo on top. I was most impressed with the balance of flavors. Even with the two meats and avocado, the lemon juice of the hollandaise cut the fattiness and rounded out the flavors perfectly. Came with the potatoes on the side and some fruit, and all together it was a hearty but not overwhelming portion. Did I mention the bacon was perfectly crispy? It was!  The service is another story. Long wait to get in, and the seating area is small to be fair so nobody should expect to be seated immediately at 10am when the place is full. When we were asked to order drinks and we said we were ready to order food too, the waitress put us on hold to run a check. I would have rather she took our drink orders and gotten them started anyway, and told us to hold on to our food orders. The 3 coffee drinks were brought out sequentially with delays in between. And at the end of the meal, we put down 3 cards, but a second lady came back to tell us we could only split between two max. On a side note, I recommend restaurants make that policy known ahead of time, which would save your waitstaff the trouble of having to make another trip to tell us.  You can be sure I'll return for the delicious eats. Again, the amount of attention to the flavors is lovely. I truly hope the community will give enough support that this yummy business will be able to hire more staff and improve efficiencies. Until then, I'll just come anticipating a leisurely meal.

vPeFdFgjI0wWRPpvfUYc5A.text: I have been coming here for years and this place has really gone down hill. Some of the worst service you will ever experience can be found here. Food is ok but not as good as it used to be.

CkHumd3RftUcKWGbIZVUMw.text: A shame. This used to be a great place for good unique food. Problem is, service is beyond deplorable. Walked in, no wait service in sight so stood by door for several minutes before someone comes out. Long story short, waited 10 minutes to get coffee, another 5 mins before putting in order. Only 3 other tables but no food on any of them after waiting another 5 mins I paid for coffee and left. "Waitress" was doubling as chef. I wasted almost 45 minutes with no food to show for it. Don't waste your time like we did.

ss3jaWZBWE9GqXwaLltugw.text: The only reason I'm giving coca cafe more than one star is because the food was good (okay). But given the service, I will not be back. The restaurant was not busy while we were there, yet our waitress could not be bothered to wait on us. For example- my friend ordered a drink, and I asked for a water and..... but before I could add coffee to my sentence she was gone. I shouted after her that I wanted an iced coffee. 15 minutes later, no coffee and no sign of her at all. 20 minutes later she is pouring hot coffee for other customers, so I begged for a cup. She begrudgingly poured me one cup of hot coffee. Then charged me for an iced coffee (more expensive). So she heard me the first time but chose not to serve me. The food is good but not this good. I've talked to several other people after eating here who had similar experiences as well. Coca cafe- you need to make some serious personnel training changes.

photos.caption: Photo of Coca Cafe - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Shakshuka. Good but not good enough.

p6MNPJXZrC22BPkvcXg1SA.text: We've been loyal patrons of coca cafe since it opened, however it's unlikely that we will ever return.   The only food that should be served on an ice cold plate is salad. Definitely nothing hot-breakfast related. No microwave? No heat lamps? No problem! There's this marvelous modern warming device called an oven, and if you place your serving plates in it, they'll be toasty warm and help keep the, what should be, warm breakfast food your customers expect to be served, warm from kitchen to table, no matter what the kitchen temperature.   Upon expecting a warm breakfast only to have it served on ice cold plates, I promptly requested my just-served ice cold over-medium eggs be immediately returned to the kitchen for some type of warming, only to get the wtf eyeroll from the waitress - yeah, I did see that. And I rarely, if ever send my food back. You all need some training on people skills!  The owner came out with a half-hearted apology about "the kitchen fans make the kitchen air 50 degrees, which severely chills the plates..." um, not an acceptable explanation or excuse or apology, frankly. It seemed more of an obligatory "apology;" one filled with contempt for the customer who was making a REASONABLE request for breakfast food to be warm. Moses, lady; I don't care that you've been in business for 12 years. If that is supposed to be some kind of testament to how good your restaurant is?...think again!  Lousy food, combined with mediocre customer skills and service will close your doors faster than you can utter the word "boo!"  Oh, yeah...did I mention that there were 3 other patrons in the restaurant and it took nearly 45 minutes to get our food...our ice cold, should-have-been-warm breakfast food!This was a Thursday, not a Sunday, as many reviews note the Sunday brunch debacle. With only 3 other patrons in the restaurant, it should not take 45 minutes to get a breakfast!  Not a "coffee or toast on the house for our indifference to your ice-cold breakfast food, maam." Nothing but a contemptful "apology."  Oy. What once was a good place to eat is now a shadow of what it once was. Go to Ritter's instead - less expensive and nicer people.  A HUGE disappointment.

c8YqPdbW1k0Bo-STxHUAew.text: I've been looking forward to checking out the brunch at Coca Cafe for a long time, as many different friends in Pittsburgh have recommended it to me. Let's be honest, brunching is one of my favorite things to do...so of course I was eagerly anticipating the experience!  Coca Cafe is small, so be prepared to wait for your table. My friend and I came at around 1 PM on a Sunday and were told that our wait would be around 30 minutes for a table - honestly, not too bad at all. Coca is BYOB, so this gave us just enough time to hike up the hill to Arsenal Cider and grab a growler of pear cider before receiving the text that our table was ready.  My expectations were quite high coming into this brunch, as I had been told many times over that Coca has one of the best brunches in Pittsburgh. My overall experience was that I was impressed, but not as impressed as I had hoped I would be. The service was great; our waiter, Tristan, was attentive and friendly. We began with one of the starters: the buttermilk donut with lemon, blueberry, and blackberry icings and powdered sugar. Truthfully, this donut was the star of the show. The donut was crisp yet fluffy, and the icing combination was phenomenal. We gobbled it up immediately.  For the main course, I ordered the avocado omelette with applewood smoked bacon and house salsa. I was concerned about the jalapeno muenster as I don't love spicy things, so I subbed in the extra-aged beemster instead. My omelette was delicious. Was it the best omelette I've ever had? I wouldn't say so. However, it was quite tasty and quite large, so I was able to bring home leftovers. It also came with a side of grilled potatoes and a small fruit cup, which complimented it well.  I love that Coca changes their menu regularly, because this means that the next time I come I can be pleasantly surprised with something new. I'm not sure if it lived up to the hype for me on this first experience, but I can see myself coming back in the near future!

photos.caption: Photo of Coca Cafe - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. The view from our table.
Photo of Coca Cafe - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Coca&#39;s current menu.
Photo of Coca Cafe - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Another shot of the buttermilk donut.

W-L8CMhf9WjFjBwDaegDxQ.text: I would really like to say haw the good is, after waiting for 40 minutes for my food I went to the counter and said I wanted to pay for my orange juice and I was leaving. The servers ran off to get the manager/ owner, not sure. She came out and said my food was almost done and said she was going to have to charge me for my whole meal. Seriously? I just told you it took 40 minutes and my food still isn't out and you want me to pay for the food I haven't gotten and am not going to get? That is just ridiculous, maybe learn how to run a restaurant instead of trying to tell my wife, a professional chef and I that it takes that long to serve breakfast.

qhusA9lhn_y-NVhpWYiLDA.text: First of all, I like the portion.  I do not eat that much in the morning, so "three-egg omelette + 15 potatoes" is not for me.  I liked the size, I liked the taste, I liked the environment.   Is the line long?  Yes.  I wanted like 45 mins+, but it was a day-off and we really wanted to try this out. Is it worth the wait?  so-so.  Just say it is slightly overrated. Not saying the food is bad, just saying the line should not be this long. There is "how many ppl come to visit" vs. "how fast they are serving the food.  Perhaps there is room for improvement. we tried their "fried eggplant Benedict" and "smoked salmon omelette". Both were excellent.  5* for the food. -1 for the wait time.  will I be back?  Only if I have a long morning with nothing else to do.  PS.  Yelp needs to fix Coca's photo page.  It's all in one album with no sub-groups...

photos.caption: Photo of Coca Cafe - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Salmon omelet
Photo of Coca Cafe - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. fried eggplant benedict ($12.5)
Photo of Coca Cafe - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. cappuccino

s0rw9gLSXw3-SCzYRPYSAg.text: The wait time for food was pretty outrageous for a Thursday morning considering it there was a handful of people in the cafe. We waited at 15 mins per drink. Our food took about 50. For omelettes. They did not have any potato side which happens. Expect our waitress did not tell us that until our food came out. She was very unapologetic and did not have good communication. When it came to divide up the check she could not get her point across that you can only spilt it with two cards. So 30 mins later. She finally rang us out. Just not a very pleasant atmosphere I was tapping my toe waiting until I could leave.

QY5jpmwEkZ8lbkUFqTHMIA.text: Yes, their service is slow (or at least when I've been there). But the food is really so good. I think it's worth it. The staff is really friendly, too. Try it and see for yourself!

fD6BWCfVzwFeJxfWnuY3kg.text: There is DEFINITELY a lot of hype around this place. I knew that right when we walked up and there was a 1.5 hour wait time. I have a friend who told me before I visited Pittsburgh, that the brunch scene was up and coming, but this one stole the cake on trendiness.   After the long wait we were finally seated and were able to place our order. We got the friend eggplant Benedict and the goat cheese and mushroom grits. The Benedict was meh, but the grits blew me away! Everything about it was perfection from the poached eggs to the mushroom balsamic glaze.   I think this place has a few kinks to work out with service, but overall I enjoyed the food.

photos.caption: Photo of Coca Cafe - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

4NN5dMLHpPvqbrM4oecaBg.text: Having read some of the reviews I was cautious about eating at the Coca Cafe.  However,  I went anyway and proved once again that you can't trust the internet. Whatever problems there were in the past have been corrected. The service was great!   Every person that works there that I came in contact with were pleasent and made the experience fun. The food was amazing!  It's made fresh and portions are filling. If you're used to 15 minute lunches...go back to McDonald's!!!  Coca has a euro feel to its pace. It's not rushed at all. TIP if you want to avoid a wait try 1pm. I love this place and will return often.

6G4YutmAXTzoeOq5n3H5cw.text: Coca Cafe had been on my to-try list for years now, and I finally stopped by for brunch last Saturday with my girl friend. We arrived a little after noon and were told that the wait would be 45 minutes. I inwardly groaned when I learned that they used the No Wait app. If only I had known and had checked in!  We spent our wait time strolling around Lawrenceville on a (very unexpected!) pretty day in January. The wait was a bit longer than the 45 minute estimate - closer to an hour - and I was suspicious when I walked back into the restaurant and saw the same large table still open in the front dining room. Did they just not seat us (or anyone else) there because our parties were too small?  I started with a glass of orange juice. It was really quite delicious, but I was very disappointed in the glass size (6 or 8 oz maybe?) that cost $3.95. I expected a much larger glass of juice for that price.  I ordered the chicken and pancakes as it sounded like a nice balance between sweet and savory. The fried chicken was actually chicken thighs. The chicken was so greasy that I had a tough time even eating half of my serving and still felt a bit sick to my stomach for the rest of the day. The pancakes were descent but just too heavy. I expected a lighter, tastier pancake to be served by a place that specializes in breakfast/brunch.  Though I had a nice time with my friend, I just wasn't blown away by the food or beverage that I ordered. However, my friend ordered an omelet and cleaned her plate. Everything looked very fresh and delicious, and the side of breakfast potatoes were just perfectly cooked and seasoned. If I come to Coca again, I'll definitely be ordering an omelet.

ADnc0DWwng-XKl4XXY7udg.text: I have intended to dine at Coca Cafe for brunch for at least 2-3 years because so many people said good things about this place. So my friend and I decided to just wake up early, arrive right when it opens, and try to beat the brunch crowd. We get there at about 9:20am and were told that there would be a 30-40 minute wait. Great. But we didn't come for nothing, so we put our name and number down and took a stroll down the street while we waited for our table.   On a typical day, I would have ordered a few other things on the menu before the one I actually ended up ordering: the eggplant benedict. I don't often like eggplant that much, so perhaps it is my fault that I didn't enjoy it, but in my defense, Coca Cafe seemed to be one of those places where everything would be good, so I thought I couldn't go wrong with any of the items on the menu. I ended up just eating barely half of it and the potatoes and fruit.   Unfortunately, for me, Coca Cafe wasn't worth the wait.   Taste | 2 Atmosphere | 3 Presentation | 3 Service | 3 OVERALL | 2.5

photos.caption: Photo of Coca Cafe - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. eggplant Benedict

TkLZ3NAr43jY-qIINVeALA.text: I've come here for brunch a few times and the food never disappoints. However, the service is soooo slow. It took a while to get coffee/espresso drinks, to order, then to get food, and finally to pay. I think we were there for over 2 hours, even though we had no wait to be seated and it wasn't crowded. Our waiter was working hard but he had to make all the drinks himself while waiting his tables, and I'm not sure what the other staff hanging around were supposed to be doing.   I still love the food, and it was a great place for BYO before because you could leisurely sip on your mimosas while waiting for service. Hopefully they make some changes to speed up service, because it doesn't do the food justice!

photos.caption: Photo of Coca Cafe - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Grilled cheese
Photo of Coca Cafe - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Omelet
Photo of Coca Cafe - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Benedict

bOdkWSooCkTe_gPp4SeBaQ.text: Told us we couldn't sit outside unless we had a dog.  Mostly empty, waited 15 minutes to order.  25 minutes til food came cold.  Cook apologized for dumping too much cinnamon on French toast...didn't do a good job of hiding how cold it was.  Service was terrible.  Baffling.

eteil7bJgnmkV7RabwL3og.text: The food is absolutely delicous, but seriously,  the wait is out of control and makes the experience not worth it. First you wait outside to get a seat, and then...you wait inside at your table for a server and your food to come out. Come on a weekday to experience the food. Come on a sunday to experience what a two hour wait is like.

YmNCrms7HbzkkbPm20swOw.text: We were visiting from Detroit and happened upon  this place. It is a breakfast cafe that serves dinner but doesn't advertise. We found this a bit strange as the food was phenomenal.  We ordered a variety of food all which were superb.  Of particular note: the Brussels sprouts were unbelievable as was the Tomato corn pie and the miso black cod which was better than Nobu at 1/5 the price.    It's a winner!!

_-fpkZRYuc343s2Zeg6jNQ.text: Food was good, but it was an hour and half wait after putting our names on the list.  After we sat down it took over 30 Minutes to get our food once orders were placed.  It was good,  but definitely wasn't worth the wait.

LYhUbfiCws-avzkZm4jY2Q.text: I've been to coca cafe several times, have wanted to love it and to give it another shot but consistently have been disappointed. I had friends in town and wanted to enjoy a nice meal together, waited 1 hour to be seated (which I'm fine with), and was completely dissatisfied with everything from start to finish.  Our server quickly gave us water and coffee but then didn't come back to take our order for 20 minutes. We sat with empty coffee cups, no refill of cream, or check in for another 30 minutes. After waiting for over an hour and listening to other tables complaining (while the staff was cleaning) I checked in with another member of the waitstaff bc our server couldn't be found to let him know we haven't received any food yet.  He proceeded to tell me that they were having "issues in the kitchen" and "there are tears everywhere." Bottom line- very inappropriate and extremely unprofessional. I definitely won't be returning, and you should take your money (bc it's definitely an overpriced establishment) elsewhere.

ZzhA-z6LnfGF0aPzNRG2yA.text: It's 3pm on Saturday and my boyfriend and I went for brunch (they closed at 5pm) and turned us away because they hadn't gotten dinner ready? They had plenty of seats and we still serving other guests. Never coming back here, poor practice to turn customers away during your business hours. Even if the food is decent they lost us as customers

yULiuB48_cyNiQ9s31qU_A.text: Some of the worst service I've experienced in a long time. The coffee drinks came without coffee in them. Instead of remaking them they just poured some espresso into whatever was left in our cups. One person never received a drink and it took 3 requests (3!!) to get that drink off our bill. The waiter explained that he kept messing this up because his coworker was rushing him to use the register. The food took an excruciatingly long time, and although it was good, it was not worth the hour and 10 minute wait for breakfast. This place is either grossly understaffed or mismanaged or both.

4dOskaRdL9Z1KGE6rslBPw.text: To be blunt: Awful service. Slow, inattentive, forgot part of our order. Took 20 minutes to take our order and an hour to get food. Food was good but not worth it. Seriously don't wait.

zlfUJVlHz-mNszYL7UAkXQ.text: Adorable little place. I loved the atmosphere, was very nice. We sat by the window for breakfast while it was snowing and I loved it! I ordered the avacado omelette which was recommended to me by the waitress. Was very good but a but bland for my taste. Husband ordered the pumpkin pancakes which apparently are only available for a couple months during winter. Pancakes were pretty amazing, very soft and creamy, absolutely delicious. Of the best tasting pancakes I've had. Portion sizes were pretty good, large for me. Oh and who can forget the fresh squeezed oj and almond mocha latte! First time I've seen or had almond mocha latte and it was nice, flavor wasn't anything crazy or too out of the box but had a nice hint of pleasant flavor from the almond.  This place is worth a try at least once!

XX4uxQwNwAl00MVX348msg.text: I love this place on a Sunday! It didn't disappoint any of the times I've gone there. I always call a little ahead to try to make sure that we wouldn't be left waiting out in the cold. Last Sunday, I took a new friend from church out for post sermon brunch. We didn't have to wait at all for a cute table in the back. We are both on the vegetarian spectrum (although eat fish), and I was a little worried that their "no substitutions" menu might pose a problem. I didn't know that their menus changed so drastically! There are now VEGAN and VEGETARIAN options. My friend ordered the Challah french toast with brie, and I enjoyed a very filling avocado omelette (sans bacon). Both were fabulous!  Honestly, I don't think you can go wrong with brunch here, just be sure to get your name on the waitlist before you come so that you are not waiting forever for a table. (Sorry Ryan K).

Y_i0djga_veIzNezN3iOyQ.text: COCA is a mainstay Lawrenceville eatery with consistently good breakfast, brunch, and lunch options.  It's definitely got a hipster vibe to the place, but not to the extreme that people over 30 feel out of place.  I own a nearby bed & breakfast and COCA is included in my short list for area eateries.  Their curried chicken salad is absolutely to die for, although I've never gotten a bad meal here.   I've not had one guest who didn't later rave about the food.  So why the four stars?  Service.  Last couple of times, even when they were not exceedingly busy, service was poor to fair.    Most recently, I went with my sister to Sunday brunch.  Maybe because there was a major thunderstorm going on outside, there was no wait and we got a table right away.  As other reviewers have mentioned, there is often a line out the door to get a table, especially for weekend brunch.  I ordered an avocado omelet, and my sister ordered a brunch special, scotch eggs  with grits.  We got our drinks right away, but waited over 30 minutes for our lunch.  While our server was uber helpful/attentive/flirty with the guy sitting adjacent to us, she was very good at ignoring us.  Just when I was about to get up to check on the food with someone other than our server, our food appeared.  But no silverware.  Another 5 minute wait for that.  And did I mention that they were not horribly busy?  I give COCA a 5 for their consistently good food (and our food that rainy day did not disappoint, it was wonderful), but service a 3.

9DP74hVcw4LPUGresxQRWQ.text: Coca Cafe is officially on my "Top-5" list for eggs benedict variations. The fried eggplant benedict with basil pesto hollandaise and roasted tomatoes was gorgeously executed. The eggs were poached perfectly and the eggplant was thinnly sliced and crispy. The ingredients married together very well.   We waited 40 minutes to be seated on a Saturday afternoon (1ish), which was to be expected. They will, however, take your telephone number and call you when your table is ready. This was appreciated, as we went down the street for coffee while we waited.   Ambiance is cute. We sat in the back (away from the door) and by the window. Would love to go back and try some other menu items like: pumpkin pancakes with ginger mascarpone cream and caramelized pears, OR the avocado omelete with apple smoked bacon, jalapeno muenster and salsa, OR the curry chicken salad with pecans, golden raisins, and mango chutney. There are SO many intriguing options.

JiM1xvEHjBBFwM5ZJTQ4Ag.text: Came here again at the suggestion from the brother and sis.  Got here around 10:30.  This is not good, as they open at 10 and they had just seemingly seated the whole place one minute before we arrived.  We waited for about 30 minutes and had some coffee and watched the list fill up behind us.    I had the french toast sandwich with ham, cheese and asparagus.  My dining partner got the puff pastry with eggs, apple sausage and brie.  The service was good.  The place was quite crowded.  This is obviously a very popular spot.  I thought it was good, but I have had better brunches.  That being said, I would return here for sure.

JDKh5GqVV49sbqAyaxLGHw.text: Coca Cafe's still squarely in the 4 star range as evidenced by another pre-work brunch with Kay after meeting with a realtor the other morning.   My Mahi Mahi tacos were rather successful and were comprised of grilled dolphinfish cubes, a fine, chunky guacamole, and a tangy red cabbage slaw all packed inside a generous trio of toasted tortillas that were garnished with a sort of remoulade. A crock of cheesy, re-fried black beans acted as a side dish, and I enjoyed them despite not usually going nutters over re-fried beans of any type.   It's worth noting that CC's menu changes often, and the tacos are not currently on the online menu, but do look for them if and when you go to CC.   P.S. Once again, if and when you visit, and you should, make sure you have plenty of time for the service at Coca Cafe is slow-going but far from incompetent or  impolite. Your food will take time to prepare. That's just how they rock here. If your employer only grants you a half-hour lunch break, this isn't the place for you (Luckily my job's a block away, and Kay had extra time to get to work).

mHvs3VO1r0bmMUEh4Z6gnQ.text: My group met for brunch this morning at 11:00 am.  We had a server that identified herself as the "front room manager".  She treated us in the rudest, most appalling and unprofessional manner.  Our server had a surley attitude right from the start.  Apparently they were short-staffed. Water glasses were slammed on the table, with water spilling on the surface, which we just quietly cleaned up ourselves. At this time there were four empty tables in the room, but she wanted the twelve of us to crowd around a table for eight, then was visibly annoyed that three of the group sat at a nearby table. Meanwhile our leader had called ahead to the restaurant but there was no answering machine-just a message left by the restaurant. As our orders were served, people asked for ice in the water, the server replied they only had bags of ice as their machine was broken. I got up and asked another server who pleasantly got me ice for my iced tea and another person's water. This "front room manager" never asked us how our food was, never offered more drinks and just as I was about to cut into my food, she grabbed my plate and said it belonged to another table. Two of our guests had to ask for their side cups of fruit-and one guest never got her fruit at all. One check was delivered with a 20% tip hilariously included!!  Two of our group had to pay with a credit card which threw her into a tizzy. She kept insisting that two separate people paying with credit cards was against their policy. When she was asked for her name, she said," I have no name" and proceeded to say she had never been treated so badly by a group. Oh, and she told two of our guests to leave the restaurant!!!!  Whoever the owner is, I hope you read this review and give some serious consideration as to whether you want this employee representing your restaurant!  We will never return and unfortunately,  I would predict your restaurant's business will continue to decline. Terrible experience!!  I would be ashamed if I owned this place

GZGOa5xMEnZk6bhwGDBe5Q.text: We got eggplant benedict and goat cheese French toast. They were both delicious and not overwhelming in portion size except the excess basil in the hollandaise.

W4NW0mhomGf7rgAM3xI8Yw.text: We waited over an hour to be seated then after receiving the text to come be seated we were told someone accidentally sat a party at our table. We were looking forward to trying this place out but will never be back.

b1O0OoPPFnYYgD9IiPGBfA.text: As a biz traveler I have honed my skill finding funky cool differnet places to eat. Working at a company down the street from Coca Cafe I stopped at the convienence store for coffee and decided to try the restaurant adjacent to the parking lot. What a lucky break because this place is amazing. I do not normally do this but it was so good I ate there twice in the same week. I had a crazy polenta cake with shrimp, avacado, pic and fried eggs, It was dynamic.. The next visit I had a corn muffin waffle with blueberry compote and a mango cream sauce. The dining room is really cool with flea retro tables from the 50's and 60's cool tunes playing at just right levels. Great wait staff who are attentive knowledgable and first rate. The chef owners have focused a balance of food atmosphere and service to create a True winner. If you dont try this place you wont know what a hip and tasty eatery is. Great Job Coca Cafe I will go out of my way to eat there again, anytime Im in the pittsburgh area.

1BrvMfpQp5focOaa4T8awg.text: I've been to Coca Cafe for brunch several times and love it each time. Yes, the wait can be horrendous on the weekends (that's kind of the thing with brunch). I get that service can be rushed on weekends too, but haven't experienced too much trouble with brunch before. I think that the thing to do with brunch foods is not to go with your typical brunch fare like omelettes, but to get their more adventurous foods. I've always been happy with the hash, the pancakes, and other interesting, innovative dishes that they have.  But the real reason that I wanted to write this review was because I finally tried their dinner. I have been walking by for months thinking that I should really go for dinner, but always think about Coca as a brunch spot. One night my husband and I had a bottle of wine in tow to grab dinner at Picollo, but there was a wait for Picollo and I was starving. We decided to go with Coca since we had never tried their dinner and there was no wait.  Well, I can't believe I waited so long to try their dinner. This was phenomenal. First, the corkage fee was minimal, which I always appreciate. We started with the charcuterie plate, which was fantastic for the most part. I'm not a huge pate fan and this was no exception, but the other meats and cheeses were great. My husband ordered the miso cod with black rice and fried Japanese okra and I ordered the BBQ duck with scallion pancakes and salad. Both were amazing! Seriously, some of the better food that I've had in quite awhile. The duck was cooked perfectly, which is hard to do (and I"m not even an huge duck fan). The scallion pancakes had a little too much batter in my opinion, but were still quite tasty. And the salad was excellent. The cod was phenomenal, truly the star of the meal. I think that it was even better than the black miso cod at Soba, which is saying something. The black rice was excellent, nutty and interesting flavored, and the fried okra was perfect (not too much batter). We saved room for a lemon cake with rhubarb compote and lemon curd, which was fantastic. It was a hot night otherwise I would have tried the doughnuts with salted caramel sauce, as those were tempting me from afar. All of this food was reasonably priced, with the whole meal coming to ~$50. Not bad for a tasty night out and leaving feeling full on great food!  The service was very nice, if not a bit odd. The two waitresses seemed to both be serving us and weren't always communicating. But that turned into more attention rather than less, so I was happy. And they were both quite nice without being invasive, so another bonus point. They may want to communicate a bit more about service, but no complaints over here.  All in all, don't forget about Coca for dinner. Brunch is great but I think they really get to flex their muscles in the dinner menu.

V582_vCOFiMOGrhzp1-e4A.text: Just had a fantastic meal here.  I've never seen so many interesting offerings in a breakfast menu!  Fried eggplant hollandaise, homemade kimchi and fried rice with eggs and scallion pancakes are just two examples!

gve2ssdgVlSOpucSel1MSA.text: We are a huge fan of Coca Cafe. The food is great: however, the last 3 times we've been here the no wait app shows 'no wait' and there is a line at the door.  The wait time for your order is 30-45 minutes and I've been looking at 2 empty tables for 20 minutes that haven't been cleared. There is too much brunch competition in Pittsburgh for any restaurant to be so lax. This is likely our last time here.

ChB93SbrQBMP70MIcKqWzA.text: Noting other reviews have mentioned a wait, we arrived at 8:30AM on Mother's Day, well ahead of the 9AM opening time.  We were eventually seated when the doors opened around 9:10AM.  They had a special brunch menu for the holiday, which offered selections from two courses, as well as mimosa or Bloody Mary.  The website hadn't mentioned the special brunch menu, but although my mother doesn't drink, I didn't mind paying a little extra for a nice brunch.  We all figured she could just order a coffee.  When the waitress finally came for our drink orders around 9:25, my mother asked about the coffee. She was told that they weren't serving coffee, and she would have to select one of the alcoholic drinks.  We're patient people, so we accept this, my mother ordered an extra mimosa that my wife enjoyed, and we walked to the cafe up the street and brought her coffee back.  Our food orders were finally taken at 9:40AM, which was odd, but I assumed the rush of opening was hectic.  Unfortunately, that's when the waiting really began.  Our first course was not served until an hour later, at 10:40AM.  The second course didn't arrive until 11:15AM.  At no point did anyone mention that the food would be so delayed, although we started to guess based on the surrounding tables.    Remember, they weren't serving coffee for this brunch.  So we were stuck inside for nearly 3 hours, in the morning, without caffeine.  That's basically the final straw for me.   We ultimately missed a scheduled tour (I'd thought allocating 2.5 hours for brunch was sufficient), and our Mother's Day celebrations were greatly curtailed.  We mentioned this to our waitress, who was less than helpful.  Basically, she said sorry, it was bad for everyone, and she just had to keep smiling.  At no point did a manager make rounds apologizing for the situation, which was very apparently uniform throughout the restaurant.    The food was pretty good, but not outstanding.  A meal with courses that are served so haphazardly just isn't the same.  For $30 a plate, there are many, many, many wonderful restaurants in Pittsburgh to enjoy, and they'll serve you in timely and pleasant fashion.  We will obviously not be returning to Coca Cafe.

hJfBCcn9ErK6lRVb0DOPdA.text: I have been meaning to try out Coca Cafe for some time now, and my friend brought me here for an end of the semester brunch celebration.  Yay for finishing my first year of graduate school!  There is no atmosphere to Coca Cafe, which I would have expected from the hipster-ish menu.  It's what I would refer to as upscale Yinzer atmosphere.  The tables are too close together so people will continuously run into you, and there will be children screaming at the tops of their lungs while their parents ignore them.  However, there are some really unique food options and the servers are pleasant enough.  I ordered an omelette with pesto, tomatoes, and feta.  It was presented very prettily, and there was a cute orange slice to give it some more color.  I wouldn't order this again necessarily, as it was too salty for my taste.  I did enjoy it, but I would prefer to try something else next time.  My friend got shrimp grits, which she raved about.  Overall, I totally prefer Coca Cafe to Square Cafe is Regent Square, and I would say that is the closest equivalent.

ssZFQ2BizC8YhbHqLEovMQ.text: If I could give zero stars I would to this dining establishment. My mother and I called this cafe early to make sure there was room the woman on the phone replied yes and there would be a table waiting for us. We arrive ten minutes later to find that was clearly not the case. We put in our name and she put us on the wait list. Twenty minutes later we were seated we ordered right away seeing how busy it was. We had coffee and water that was never refilled and we waited another hour and a half and our food never came. Finally my mother asked if the food was ever coming out to which our waitress replied there are other people waiting for food. She walked away without asking if we needed anything. At this point I look around to realize that there is not a single table with food on it. People there before and the staff is pretty much standing around. Finally my mother walks up saying that she wishes to pay for coffee but we must leave. The woman replies "can I just say that you haven't been waiting that long. No one else is being uptight" To which then my dad says we are leaving and not paying for the coffee. The staff is appalling and the time we spent there was atrocious. The service was awful for mediocre, overpriced brunch food.

FSVarVtm1Oq7WLGFcYRWzA.text: A friend and I decided to grab some brunch at Coca Cafe on a Friday at 11pm. It had been over a year since my last visit, and I remembered from that experience that it had unique offerings and the kind of bustle that you want at your Saturday brunch spot.   On a Friday, you don't get the same "bustle" that you get on a Saturday. We were sat without a wait, and our waitress was quite quick to get us water and coffee. When she brought out the water, it was lukewarm. (Side note: the previous night I had just returned from a trip to China, where there is not a bottle of cold water in the entire country. Needless to say, I was used to water this temperature, but I missed ice cubes dearly. It could have been colder).   I ordered the green shakshuka and my friend ordered the eggplant Benedict. Last time I had been there, I also ordered the shakshuka, but the recipe had changed drastically. The food took a while to arrive at our table despite the emptiness of the restaurant. The shakshuka was the perfect portion size; however it was a tad overcooked. The egg yolks were quite hard, and the vegetables seemed to have a noticeable singed aftertaste and a thick, dry texture. Nonetheless, the sauce was herbaceous with an interesting, earthy flavor. I'd eat it again for sure while crossing my fingers and hoping its not overcooked. The potatoes on the side seemed slightly bland in my opinion, but I tend to enjoy things a bit spicier.   After we finished our meals, the waitress took a while to get us our check and, while the receipt reflected that I had spent more on my meal than my friend, she ended up charging our credit cards evenly.   Conclusion: food is unique and delicious despite being cooked inconsistently, and service is slow.

ShMp3ylGzyx_LV5iFhhnWQ.text: The best brunch place in Pittsburgh, hands down. Located in the super hipster Lawrenceville, this place is my go-to restaurant for a great start to the day. It has this cute diner vibe and is always packed with people. They don't take reservations for brunch - you can call and put your name on the list so its first come/call, first serve. But trust me, it is 110% worth the wait.  For your beverages, make sure you order one of their freshly squeezed juices. They make it in house and have such wonderful concoctions. I'm particularly fond of their pear honeydew pineapple juice. It is just the right level of sweet and tart. You'll have to stir it a bit occasionally for the consistency to be right. It is SO SO SO good though. I've also tried the matcha tea latte, which wasn't the best I've had. The matcha tasted a bit funky, and the latte itself wasn't made that well.  Anyway, on to the starters. Banana bread with honey walnut cream cheese and fruit? Amazing. Bread is wonderfully moist and soft - not stale at all and not too sweet. Avocado toast with a drizzle of honey? My favorite. Sounds like a strange combo but I promise you it just works.  Brunch menu always changes when I go, which makes it exciting. I've tried their pumpkin pancakes with maple butter and caramelized pears. The pancakes are so soft and you probably won't be able to finish them (HUGE portion size) . The pears were my favorite part. If you have a giant sweet tooth, this is your dish.  I've also had their scallop eggs benedict. It's not on their website menu since I guess it's a rotational one, but I loved it. I think it's my favorite brunch dish I've had there. The scallops were so large and juicy and went perfectly with the hollandaise sauce. Normally, with eggs benedict, restaurants kind of just give up on the English muffin part and it's just that - a plain English muffin. But they toasted it here and did something with it to make it stand out to me (I don't know what).  Another thing I've tried is their house cured and tea-smoked salmon omelet with goat cheese, dill, and roasted tomatoes. The goat cheese threw me off at first (wasn't expecting it in an omelet, or with salmon), but it was surprisingly pretty good. This was your standard breakfast omelet with a twist.   Finally, I've also tried the savory duck crepe with Asian slaw and two sunny side up eggs. This dish was interesting. Slaw wasn't my favorite, but then again, I never like slaw. Eggs were fine. Duck was fine. I think it was just confusing to me in the way they presented the dish. They hid the crepe part on the bottom, covering it with the duck confit, slaw and eggs. I completely missed the crepe part until I ate through the dish and saw it, and by then, it was all soggy and unappealing. I wish they had presented it in a way where it preserved the integrity of the "crepe," especially as they were calling it a crepe dish.   Otherwise, this place is truly a neighborhood gem. It's also a short walk from Espresso A Mano, a fantastic coffee shop. Smaller groups fare better here and be ready to wait at least 30 minutes if you come on a popular brunch day!

Photo of Coca Cafe - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Coca Cafe - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Scallops egg Benedict

GiwEFC54nuy8D9tBuxRo1Q.text: Went for lunch on a Saturday around 1:30pm, and waited for about 15 minutes before getting seated. (Street parking is easy to find, btw). We first ordered drinks, which took a little while to be served (10 minutes). Then came the wait. We waited for about 30+ minutes for the food to get onto the table, from the time of ordering. Basically we ate for around 15 minutes, and spent the rest of the time waiting. The other tables around us seemed to be waiting for a long time as well, so I guess it's just the norm at this spot.  As for the food, it was okay. I wouldn't come back here for lunch though given the wait times. We got three dishes - Korean beef salad, chopped chicken romaine salad, and the special pumpkin pancakes of the day. The beef salad was pretty good, a 4/5. The chicken salad was nothing special, a 3.5/5. The pumpkin pancakes were pretty good, a 4/5.  All in all, I'd give this place a 3.5. 3 for service, and 3.5 for food.

yP16JnWXyrJaZMC4Nk4glA.text: This place used to be my absolute FAVORITE restaurant in Pittsburgh, maybe in the world. Unfortunately, that was a couple years ago, and Coca Cafe isn't quite the same anymore. What used to be a quaint eatery with friendly staff and amazing food has turned into a snobby, unwelcoming, poorly run establishment. Walking in on a weekend morning, it's generally busy. You put your name on a list and, if you're lucky, wait about 45 minutes to an hour. Get unlucky, and you might just be stuck with a wait time close to 2 hours. There is nowhere to wait, and you are sent half a mile down the street to the nearest coffee shop by a rude hostess who really couldn't care less about you.  This is just the beginning. The most recent time I have been here, I was met with another 30 minute wait- until the waitress even noticed we were there. No water, coffee, menus...nothing. For half an hour.  She finally found us, and did not apologize. In fact, my friends and I felt like we were bothering her by asking for drinks. We finally ordered, and waited AN HOUR for our french toast and eggs. When the food came it was soggy, not fresh, and frankly not of the quality I remember so fondly from a few years ago.  By the end, we wanted nothing more than to get the hell out of there and pretend we didn't just overpay for crappy food and a disappointing experience.

FOVw_eql1c2H91QDMUT9hg.text: I still stand by their blueberry lemon pancakes. So fluffy with delicate hints of lemon and full of blueberries.   I decided to try their savory dishes and ordered the Eggplant Benedict. It was decent. Crispy eggplant on an English muffin with sun-dried tomatoes. The poached egg was nice and runny. It came with a side of roast potatoes and a fruit cup. I did enjoy the pancakes I had before much more.  I didn't call ahead for a reservation this time and we had to wait about 30 min. to be seated. We were able to put our name down and they called us when a table was open. We just stopped by Espresso a Mano to get some drinks during our wait. Espresso a Mano also has great biscotti like Coca Cafe.

photos.caption: Photo of Coca Cafe - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Salmon Omelette
Photo of Coca Cafe - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Eggplant Benedict

k3E-vJ-5_mJzoXnLJ0ip3A.text: How is this place rated one of Pittsburgh's best brunch spots? I'm only giving one star because you can't give 0! Service was horrible, food was cold and overpriced, and of all things the Bloody Mary tasted like pure pickle juice. I asked the waitress, who was literally walking out the door to go home, if there was a problem because we had waited 1.5 hours for eggs and there were only about 7 ppl in the whole restaurant. She said, "this is normal" and that "they can only cook 3 plates at a time"! She was right. We got 3 out of 4 meals, no sides, and it was just eggs, nothing special. Next brunch will be home or the Grand Concourse. If I'm going to spend $40 for eggs and a Bloody Mary at least the chef will cook it to my liking while I wait and chat. Literally will NEVER go back!

4W4eR2PAE6NvtBWXQo6Z3g.text: I came here last year and fell in love with the place- food and drinks were amazing for brunch and service was great! I just revisited the place this week, and oh boy have things changed. it took 25 minutes for my cappuccino to come out, and i had to ask for it to be remade because it had zero foam (and i hate sending things back!) it took ANOTHER 30 minutes for our APPETIZER to come out and another 20 minutes for our breakfast!!! so unbelievably slow. The food was still amazing hence why i'm giving it 2 stars instead of one, but the service was so bad we literally saw 3 separate parties leave because they weren't waited on. I don't know what's happen to the place but they are severely understaffed

YdOrkoqKkXHTcHEgZFhvFQ.text: Coca is very charming and cozy. You're greeted right as you walk in the door!   I stopped here one morning when I was in Lawrenceville for an interview. I needed a quick breakfast and I felt bad that I couldn't linger longer - I barely ate any of my food because it took a while to be served, even though they didn't seem too busy. My salty caramel latte was delicious, even though it was so hot it scalded my tongue!   I'll definitely be back when I have more time to kill.

photos.caption: Photo of Coca Cafe - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pumpkin pancakes with caramelized pears and bacon!
Photo of Coca Cafe - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. A salty caramel latte

47DzLEkwbsz1JTRK2VAilA.text: Ate there for lunch yesterday. Wonderful! I wanted the brussel sprouts, but they were out, so she threw together a quick veggie saute with red peppers, zucchini ribbons, carrot ribbons, onions, etc., topped with some goat cheese and a couple dollops of pesto. Heavenly! They should add it to the menu! My friend got the BLT bowl, with added chicken. Also very good!

MySaFJ7F75ZBlKZr0zqQGQ.text: This place is super cute. The area in general is super cute.  Came here for breakfast with a friend and was splendidly surprised by the awesome atmosphere and eclectic decor. I got the tea smoked salmon, goat cheese omelette with potatoes. It was very yummy and the portions were good for the price. My friend got the avocado omelette which he really liked as well. It's a family friendly place.  There is ample parking nearby and they also have some outdoor seating. The line can be long, but they will call you when a table is available, which allows you to roam around while waiting.  Will def come by again.

ARzMcwNBap61yr--44O5mg.text: I've been here once with my husband and the food we had was definitely 10/10 (I had the cheesy omelette with bacon added and he had the avocado omelette). I would say the service leaves something to be desired as we walked up to the bar and were asked if we were on "the list". To which we confusedly responded no. The hostess/waitress then sat us at one of the many empty tables we were surrounded by. The only other thing I would say about the service is that we were left alone for a while which made brunch take a while longer than it needed to. Otherwise the food was great!

DIfB32-TFO4XX77XP0Z4fQ.text: Coffee was quick and delicious.  Also, using "No-Wait" got us in there pretty quickly.  Last plus:  menu is interesting.  HOWEVER, that is the end of the positive points, sadly.  Service is slow and no one checked on us--I got up three times to:  ask for water and more coffee, find out where our food was (waited almost an hour), and to get our bill.  They tried to make up for the endless waiting with a raspberry donut but that, too, tasted like oil and was dry.  Lots of other customers had the same problems.  I miss the old Coco...  Please get some additional kitchen staff and train your wait staff.  It's not like they are busy bringing out food!!

p92Yhn0N5FVk-LvQHfUWGw.text: Loved this place. We got here shortly after 9 so we were able to get a table right away. I got the mushroom omelet and it was seriously the best omelet I have ever eaten in my life. My only complaint is the food took awhile to come to the table but it was well worth the wait. Thought the place was moderately priced. Will definitely be back.

agxUFWKAZEdE5ovTKwLcJA.text: One visit, and I rarely say (well, never say) things like this about a place on one visit.  Our group of 4 was scheduled to go to Coca Cafe for about 3 weeks.  Arrived and reservations were perfect and wew set by a nice window seat for late afternoon St. Pat's day celebrations.  Place is immaculate, and oddly retro artsy.  A fun exploration visually, and with a walk around to the sunny back room area, one could see just how much space they had created in this small area for customers.  There is even an outdoor seating area (for later this spring).  BYOB but a very minimal PER TABLE corkage.  None of the rip off per bottle regardless of how small or large your party might be. The fact they do a PER TABLE corkage has now ruled out even experimenting with places that was a $5-7 per bottle...   Really?  Seated immediately; water to table; drinks very fast indeed.  We ordered a cheese plate sampler -- the goat cheese / blue cheese (forgot the name) was excellent.  Explanation of the range of cheeses professional. Slow, even pace of visits by the waitress -- no rush, no push, even as the place was filling up.  FYI -- when we left at 8, there was not a single seat available in the place.  As we were readying to go, there were two more groups ready for our table.  They are doing something right. But were not under any pressure to move and relax where we were.  None.    Brisket, Brisket, sake marinated Cod -- all perfectly done with extra care on the presentation.  Anyone can slop food on a plate but few groups know how to properly arrange it visually.  White China -- what else.  The Cod marinade was done exactly correctly.  Most fu-fu places cook the fish until it is unrecognizable -- this was done closer to the raw side, which is my favorite (specially if one has lived in Japan and understand a bit about actual fish that is not-flash frozen.  Double espresso was nice.  Wine service could not have been better.  As the cafe loaded up with so many people, the waitresses were becoming stretched, BUT, honestly had everyone under control.  Busing to/from tables gentile.  Kitchen staff filtered out as necessary to keep things moving.  This felt like a slow meal in Athens, Greece actually, or an off broadway bistro in NYC. On a slower night we probably would have stayed another hour and chatted more.   Menu was 14" long and narrow.  With fresh paper for each.  None of crap recycle plastic over paper one finds so often. We were tempted for dessert but the meal was ample.  Next time, we will start with desserts...  Prices were very reasonable for the quality of experience.    A dozen (yes) people came by carrying their bottles of wine and looked in the window to realize it was full, then moved on.  Noses pressed to the glass type of looking in...   We are interested in a repeat visit for the breakfast and brunch, then a visit to the strip district perhaps.    Some reviews from a year ago have "issues."  I didn't see a single issue last night worthy of any comment.  I wish Coca Cafe had a place up in the Cranberry area which is apparently the "good food desert" for western PA.  f8 and be there.

41EOnGqP3HqTts6xAvMA8g.text: SETTING Clean interior with tables positioned close together in a tight space. Loud chatter and background noise during a Sunday brunch.  FOOD Unique and tasty brunch offerings, which is the main reason I like this spot. Pancakes and waffles are delicious and all, but occasionally my taste buds crave something more exotic. Coca Cafe does the job right.   I've always gotten the Fried Eggplant Benedict. If this is your first time here, get this now and thank me later. Not a huge fan of eggplant? Don't worry, it doesn't have an overwhelming taste. Two servings of fried eggplant and poached eggs on top of its own english muffin, topped with roasted tomatoes and doused in--wait for it--BASIL hollandaise sauce. Tasted a bit like pesto mixed in with hollandaise sauce, and let me tell you, it was heavenly.  This time I ventured out and tried a new dish. The Smoked salmon omelet was solid, but it felt like something was missing...maybe some sort of sauce would have taken it to a new level. Along with bits of salmon, the omelet also had a generous amount of goat cheese, a bit of dill, and a few sliced baby tomatoes inside. I'm pretty sure it was a typo on the menu because instead of "smoked" salmon, it was "cooked" salmon. Still good, but it wasn't what was advertised. If it had some sort of sauce to add to the texture and provide a sort of moistness, I think it could become a very good dish. For now, I'll stick with the Eggplant Benedict.  SERVICE I've never waited so long (on premise) for food before. Put our phone number down and was told 1 hour 15 min. After waiting the full length of time, we went back to check on our status. Apparently they wrote down the wrong phone number or something since they claimed they called but we never got it. After finally being seated, it took another 20 or so minutes to get our food. Total time we waited from putting down our name to food on table was 2 hours!!! NOT COOL. The atmosphere seemed kinda of hectic. Lots of movement, loud chatter from other nearby tables, and long waits. This is probably the main reason I don't come that much, but if I do, I go right when they open.   IMPRESSIONS At first thought, "adventurous" and "comfort food" don't seem to go together, but neither do Leonardo DiCaprio and Rihanna. I was wrong, on both counts!    You know a certain dish like the Fried Eggplant Benedict is special when you only associate it with the one restaurant, and you can't seem to muster the courage to order something else every time you visit. Just make sure you come early. Or you might be waiting 2 hours :(

6qBkZ49mgIWHMFrByCuw1w.text: Still my favorite brunch spot, even with a growing number of offerings. Dishes are hearty & creative, always good presentation & decent brunch drinks!

4aFAN5aS0Y873KNhBlkAvQ.text: Two words: Breakfast. Pizza. Two slices of thick-cut bread topped with herbed cheese and Parmesan spread, greens and seared tomatoes, sunny-side up eggs, and deliciously seasoned sausage. youtube.com/watch?v=SMWi...

1ovVA2OXqA_6XFxu-jovCw.text: This place was delicious! The ingredients are fresh and there are traditional and funky options. The pumpkins pancakes were INCREDIBLE! I wasn't as big of a fan of the mushroom omelet (a little boring). But the omelet with goat cheese or feta (I forget which one) was amazing!

3NIED7P_wGmwOWFDBRJDOg.text: Just got back from trying this place for the first time.  Right up front, *enormous* bonus points for the best restaurant website I've seen in months; the front page has address and hours in easy to find, clear text.  (Is that so much to ask of all the other restaurants around?)  They had every table full on a friday at noon, but no wait, which was good.  Definitely seemed like a place best well-timed; avoid busier times of the day, I think.  Service was very friendly, and a hair slow due to the full restaurant.  That said, the white omelette was good, as was the brie-stuffed french toast.  Both could have used a touch more cheese, maybe; not sure if anyone else would agree, as I really love some cheese.  Cinnamon bread was surprisingly understated and awesome.  The art on the walls was actually first-class, which was more than a little surprising to me.  I'll head back soon.
